item.title: TEAM
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
Teamwork is the only way this work can happen.

It's how God designed it. When likeminded people work together for God's glory, the impossible happens. We are humbled to witness the impossible day after day. Here's who we are:

The Core

item.title: men | Lionheart Sessions
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
christian living > men > lionheart sessions vol. 1

The Pursuit is a four week curriculum designed to engage the men in your parish into the life of the Church.

Purchase Now

THE POWER OF MENTORING

"Men need good men, especially our priest, to commiserate with, to vent, to normalize what we feel, problem solve and help us to follow Christ."

Bishop JOHN (Abdalah)

The Pursuit of Authenticity

We blast through some false ideals about manhood, and instead, we introduce the concept that real men take all that they were in their boyhood and grow it up to serve.

The Pursuit of Intentionality

Becoming a man means we have to focus less on trying to be something, and more on how we intentionally choose to relate to other.

The Pursuit of Priorities

Learn how to identify temptations and put them into proper perspective. Our team will equip you with alternatives to succumbing to temptation and a road-map to connect to your inner life.

The Pursuit of God

Men need to be in relationship. Men need other men. And in the Orthodox Church, we also know that men need committed participation in the life of the Church community.

Purchase Now

Try before you buy.

View session one for free

[contact-form-7 id="342" title="Lionheart Sessions"]

Engage the men in your church.

What's included in the starter kit:

  • 4 Video Sessions
  • 1 Leader Guide
  • 10 Participant Workbooks
  • Digital collateral to customize and print.

Purchase Options

Starter Kit

item.content:encoded: This is an example of a WordPress page, you could edit this to put information about yourself or your site so readers know where you are coming from. You can create as many pages like this one or sub-pages as you like and manage all of your content inside of WordPress.

item.title: STORY
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
When Faithtree Resources began just two years ago, we had no idea God would use our little parish in Van Nuys, California and our small team of volunteers to reach thousands of people across the world through this work. We were just creating content and conversations for the people in our pews.

You see, Faithtree Resources started as a local effort designed to help the people of one parish, St. Michael Antiochian Orthodox Church, in Van Nuys, CA, bring their faith to life. We had begun looking for answers to questions like, "Why are so many people disengaged in our churches?" "Why is there such a disconnect between the teachings of Holy Scripture and how we live our lives?" "How come so many young people express the belief that the Orthodox Church is no longer relevant for daily living?" And most importantly, "Where is everyone?!"

With a seed donation of just $5000, the team of Faithtree Resources set out to find those answers. Beginning our work on the local level, with an inaugural meeting attended by three people and the priest, we soon found out that many people were looking for answers to those exact same question.

With the cyber world being what it is, very quickly, people from around the world started accessing our content online, and by the end of year one, almost 1500 people had attended our live events.

Today, just 2 years from inception, Faithtree Resources has served tens of thousands of Christians across the world with programs, live events, book, small group curriculum, research papers, ministry-starter, video teachings, on-line training and more. The response has been humbling. The demand has been overwhelming. God is good.

Faithtree is growing far more quickly than our team could have ever imagined just two short years ago. We are grateful that our God has allowed us to take part in this work and look forward to what He enables us to do next. Take a look and see how good the Lord is!

Faithtree Resources began just two years ago, we had no idea God would use our little parish in Van Nuys, California and our small team of volunteers to reach thousands of people across the world through this work. We were just creating content and conversations for the people in our pews.
You see, Faithtree Resources started as a local effort designed to help the people of one parish, St. Michael Antiochian Orthodox Church, in Van Nuys, CA, bring their faith to life. We had begun looking for answers to questions like, "Why are so many people disengaged in our churches?" "Why is there such a disconnect between the teachings of Holy Scripture and how we live our lives?" "How come so many young people express the belief that the Orthodox Church is no longer relevant for daily living?" And most importantly, "Where is everyone?!"
With a seed donation of just $5000, the team of Faithtree Resources set out to find those answers. Beginning our work on the local level, with an inaugural meeting attended by three people and the priest, we soon found out that many people were looking for answers to those exact same question.";s:10:"margin_top";s:0:"";s:17:"margin_top_medium";s:0:"";s:21:"margin_top_responsive";s:0:"";s:13:"margin_bottom";s:0:"";s:20:"margin_bottom_medium";s:0:"";s:24:"margin_bottom_responsive";s:0:"";s:11:"margin_left";s:0:"";s:18:"margin_left_medium";s:0:"";s:22:"margin_left_responsive";s:0:"";s:12:"margin_right";s:0:"";s:19:"margin_right_medium";s:0:"";s:23:"margin_right_responsive";s:0:"";s:18:"responsive_display";s:0:"";s:18:"visibility_display";s:0:"";s:26:"visibility_user_capability";s:0:"";s:9:"animation";s:0:"";s:15:"animation_delay";s:3:"0.0";s:2:"id";s:0:"";s:5:"class";s:0:"";s:4:"type";s:9:"rich-text";}}s:13:"5a01d4e8934f6";O:8:"stdClass":5:{s:4:"node";s:13:"5a01d4e8934f6";s:4:"type";s:6:"module";s:6:"parent";s:13:"5a01d49a94679";s:8:"position";i:0;s:8:"settings";O:8:"stdClass":21:{s:4:"text";s:796:"With the cyber world being what it is, very quickly, people from around the world started accessing our content online, and by the end of year one, almost 1500 people had attended our live events.
Today, just 2 years from inception, Faithtree Resources has served tens of thousands of Christians across the world with programs, live events, book, small group curriculum, research papers, ministry-starter, video teachings, on-line training and more. The response has been humbling. The demand has been overwhelming. God is good.
Faithtree is growing far more quickly than our team could have ever imagined just two short years ago. We are grateful that our God has allowed us to take part in this work and look forward to what He enables us to do next. Take a look and see how good the Lord is!";s:10:"margin_top";s:0:"";s:17:"margin_top_medium";s:0:"";s:21:"margin_top_responsive";s:0:"";s:13:"margin_bottom";s:0:"";s:20:"margin_bottom_medium";s:0:"";s:24:"margin_bottom_responsive";s:0:"";s:11:"margin_left";s:0:"";s:18:"margin_left_medium";s:0:"";s:22:"margin_left_responsive";s:0:"";s:12:"margin_right";s:0:"";s:19:"margin_right_medium";s:0:"";s:23:"margin_right_responsive";s:0:"";s:18:"responsive_display";s:0:"";s:18:"visibility_display";s:0:"";s:26:"visibility_user_capability";s:0:"";s:9:"animation";s:0:"";s:15:"animation_delay";s:3:"0.0";s:2:"id";s:0:"";s:5:"class";s:0:"";s:4:"type";s:9:"rich-text";}}}

item.title: PARTNERS
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
Faithtree Resources has been blessed with multiple brave partners who were willing to take a chance on a brand new ministry, and trusted our small team of volunteers to steward their resources well. We are indebted to their trust, and inspired by their commitment to seeing Orthodox Christians further know and live the Faith.

And hundreds of individuals committed to this work

item.title: REASON
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
Our Why

There are so many reasons we think our mission is a critical one for the North American Church at this time.

We can no longer borrow the faith of our parents

Research from Pew Charitable Trusts` U.S. Religious Knowledge Survey illustrates that less than a 1/3 of American Christians can correctly answer 50% of questions about the core teachings, history, and leading figures of their faith traditions. 57% of American Christians believe other religions can lead to eternal life (Ponce Foundation). If we are ever to actively pursue putting Christ's teachings into daily practice, we must know what they are. If we are going to claim to be Orthodox Christians, we simply mush know what that means. What does it require we do, and alternatively, what does it require we don't do? Faithtree supports priests, people and parishes in answering these questions by creating engaging and interactive resources that teach the Faith, in the fullness of the Orthodox understanding and ethos, and taught by some of the Orthodox Church's most seasoned clergy, theologians and professionals. We envision a future where all of us seek to actively grow in our spiritual life, and not simply rely on the history of our forefathers.

Many of us don't read the salvific Gospel of Jesus Christ

According to the Barna Group and the American Bible Society, we Americans love our Bibles-we just don't want to read them. Less than 25% of Americans said they read their Bible on a regular basis (four or more times a week). A Gallup Poll reports that nearly 50% of Christians who attend church weekly do not believe that the Bible is the actual Word of God. This is no different for Orthodox Christians. A growing identification of the need to connect the timeless principles of Holy Scripture and the ever-present problems of day-to-day living is unmistakable. One of the things that makes the Faithtree team most excited is our passion about teaching in the language of our day. We don't use too many $10 words. While we understand we will never fully grasp all that the Orthodox Faith, or our Holy Tradition offers us, we are passionate about helping people engage from where they are. This is an intentional effort to help bridge the gap between the past and the present, the conceptual and the practical and to address the growing expressed concern that the Church is'too hard to understand'.

Many of us have stopped going to church

Pew Research Center for Religion and Public Life reports that only 36% of adults in America attend religious services at least once a week. For Orthodox Christians, that percentage is even smaller (31%). We at Faithtree Resources understand the local parish to be the most important place for our people to engage. We don't believe we should 'do church' online, or that we can just "pray it out at home alone". At Faithtree Resources, we want to support relationships with spiritual mentors like the priest. We want our people to value and participate actively in the sacramental life of the Church. And we think it should all happen at the local parish.

 

We are called to share the fullness of the Truth of the Good New of Jesus Christ, which is most fully expressed in the One, Holy, Catholic and Apostolic Church.

Many folks today lack the deep understanding of how applying the teachings of the Church can directly impact their life for the Kingdom, and for the better. Application is putting into practice what we already know (see Mark 4:24 and Hebrews 5:14) and answers the question of "Why does it matter>" Faithtree believes that by doing that as Christ showed us0in community and together, that can happen most fully.

Our How

With a mission to aid our communities in helping Orthodox Christians to live like Christians, our team has begun to think of ourselves as:

Protectors. Not like Superman, or the Armed Forces, of course. But rather, our team thinks of ourselves as protectors of people, resources and Tradition. We take extraordinary efforts to ensure that we are protecting the people who work with us and for us. For the most part, we are volunteers, but we are committed to protecting our team and preserving a focus on the spiritual life, which means we pray together. A lot. We also are committed to protecting the Holy Tradition of the Ancient Christian Faith. This means we work with clergy and theologians to ensure that our teachings are theologically accurate. It means we work with doctors, teachers, youth workers, etc.,to make sure our resources are edifying and beneficial for our audience. And it means we stretch and steward every dollar we are entrusted with to its fullest capacity and to the best of our abilities. We take people's trust in us very seriously.

Collaborators.Listen, it takes a village, that's for sure. To live out the Christian faith in this day and age, we need a tribe! And by working collaboratively with hierarchs, priests, theologians, therapist, doctors, educators, lay leaders and other seaoned thinkers from all over the Orthodox Church, we ensure our materialls are vetted through the eyes of many trusted leaders, many times. Side bonus is collaboration also makes the work super fun.

The Application Police. Perhaps the Faithtree team's biggest passion is focusing on application. This means a relentless pursuit of educating in simple, practical and immediately applicable ways. The Orthodox Christian Faith is so rich, so full of God's Truth in its fullness. But if we don't know how to actually apply it, what good does it do us?

Translators. Okay, this word is tricky, because we're not Biblical Scholars (though we've worked with quite a few on our materials), and we aren't linguistics specialist, either (worked with a few of those, as well). So saying we are translators might seem a bit deceitful. However, we are committed to translating the teachings of the Faith into a language our people understand. That may look like digital media, it may look like great story-telling, but by speaking in the language of our day, we can share the Good News of Jesus Christ in a way our people can listen to, and God willing, hear.

Our Why

There are so many reasons we think our mission is a critical one for the North American Church at this time.

We can no longer borrow the faith of our parents

Research from Pew Charitable Trusts` U.S. Religious Knowledge Survey illustrates that less than a 1/3 of American Christians can correctly answer 50% of questions about the core teachings, history, and leading figures of their faith traditions. 57% of American Christians believe other religions can lead to eternal life (Ponce Foundation). If we are ever to actively pursue putting Christ's teachings into daily practice, we must know what they are. If we are going to claim to be Orthodox Christians, we simply mush know what that means. What does it require we do, and alternatively, what does it require we don't do? Faithtree supports priests, people and parishes in answering these questions by creating engaging and interactive resources that teach the Faith, in the fullness of the Orthodox understanding and ethos, and taught by some of the Orthodox Church's most seasoned clergy, theologians and professionals. We envision a future where all of us seek to actively grow in our spiritual life, and not simply rely on the history of our forefathers.

Many of us don't read the salvific Gospel of Jesus Christ

According to the Barna Group and the American Bible Society, we Americans love our Bibles-we just don't want to read them. Less than 25% of Americans said they read their Bible on a regular basis (four or more times a week). A Gallup Poll reports that nearly 50% of Christians who attend church weekly do not believe that the Bible is the actual Word of God. This is no different for Orthodox Christians. A growing identification of the need to connect the timeless principles of Holy Scripture and the ever-present problems of day-to-day living is unmistakable. One of the things that makes the Faithtree team most excited is our passion about teaching in the language of our day. We don't use too many $10 words. While we understand we will never fully grasp all that the Orthodox Faith, or our Holy Tradition offers us, we are passionate about helping people engage from where they are. This is an intentional effort to help bridge the gap between the past and the present, the conceptual and the practical and to address the growing expressed concern that the Church is'too hard to understand'.

Many of us have stopped going to church

Pew Research Center for Religion and Public Life reports that only 36% of adults in America attend religious services at least once a week. For Orthodox Christians, that percentage is even smaller (31%). We at Faithtree Resources understand the local parish to be the most important place for our people to engage. We don't believe we should 'do church' online, or that we can just "pray it out at home alone". At Faithtree Resources, we want to support relationships with spiritual mentors like the priest. We want our people to value and participate actively in the sacramental life of the Church. And we think it should all happen at the local parish.

 

We are called to share the fullness of the Truth of the Good New of Jesus Christ, which is most fully expressed in the One, Holy, Catholic and Apostolic Church.

Many folks today lack the deep understanding of how applying the teachings of the Church can directly impact their life for the Kingdom, and for the better. Application is putting into practice what we already know (see Mark 4:24 and Hebrews 5:14) and answers the question of "Why does it matter>" Faithtree believes that by doing that as Christ showed us0in community and together, that can happen most fully.

Not like Superman, or the Armed Forces, of course. But rather, our team thinks of ourselves as protectors of people, resources and Tradition. We take extraordinary efforts to ensure that we are protecting the people who work with us and for us. For the most part, we are volunteers, but we are committed to protecting our team and preserving a focus on the spiritual life, which means we pray together. A lot. We also are committed to protecting the Holy Tradition of the Ancient Christian Faith. This means we work with clergy and theologians to ensure that our teachings are theologically accurate. It means we work with doctors, teachers, youth workers, etc.,to make sure our resources are edifying and beneficial for our audience. And it means we stretch and steward every dollar we are entrusted with to its fullest capacity and to the best of our abilities. We take people's trust in us very seriously. Collaborators.Listen, it takes a village, that's for sure. To live out the Christian faith in this day and age, we need a tribe! And by working collaboratively with hierarchs, priests, theologians, therapist, doctors, educators, lay leaders and other seaoned thinkers from all over the Orthodox Church, we ensure our materialls are vetted through the eyes of many trusted leaders, many times. Side bonus is collaboration also makes the work super fun.";s:10:"margin_top";s:0:"";s:17:"margin_top_medium";s:0:"";s:21:"margin_top_responsive";s:0:"";s:13:"margin_bottom";s:0:"";s:20:"margin_bottom_medium";s:0:"";s:24:"margin_bottom_responsive";s:0:"";s:11:"margin_left";s:0:"";s:18:"margin_left_medium";s:0:"";s:22:"margin_left_responsive";s:0:"";s:12:"margin_right";s:0:"";s:19:"margin_right_medium";s:0:"";s:23:"margin_right_responsive";s:0:"";s:18:"responsive_display";s:0:"";s:18:"visibility_display";s:0:"";s:26:"visibility_user_capability";s:0:"";s:9:"animation";s:0:"";s:15:"animation_delay";s:3:"0.0";s:2:"id";s:0:"";s:5:"class";s:0:"";s:4:"type";s:9:"rich-text";}}s:13:"5a01db7d5fb53";O:8:"stdClass":5:{s:4:"node";s:13:"5a01db7d5fb53";s:4:"type";s:6:"module";s:6:"parent";s:13:"5a01db5e1c145";s:8:"position";i:0;s:8:"settings";O:8:"stdClass":21:{s:4:"text";s:981:"The Application Police. Perhaps the Faithtree team's biggest passion is focusing on application. This means a relentless pursuit of educating in simple, practical and immediately applicable ways. The Orthodox Christian Faith is so rich, so full of God's Truth in its fullness. But if we don't know how to actually apply it, what good does it do us? Translators. Okay, this word is tricky, because we're not Biblical Scholars (though we've worked with quite a few on our materials), and we aren't linguistics specialist, either (worked with a few of those, as well). So saying we are translators might seem a bit deceitful. However, we are committed to translating the teachings of the Faith into a language our people understand. That may look like digital media, it may look like great story-telling, but by speaking in the language of our day, we can share the Good News of Jesus Christ in a way our people can listen to, and God willing, hear.";s:10:"margin_top";s:0:"";s:17:"margin_top_medium";s:0:"";s:21:"margin_top_responsive";s:0:"";s:13:"margin_bottom";s:0:"";s:20:"margin_bottom_medium";s:0:"";s:24:"margin_bottom_responsive";s:0:"";s:11:"margin_left";s:0:"";s:18:"margin_left_medium";s:0:"";s:22:"margin_left_responsive";s:0:"";s:12:"margin_right";s:0:"";s:19:"margin_right_medium";s:0:"";s:23:"margin_right_responsive";s:0:"";s:18:"responsive_display";s:0:"";s:18:"visibility_display";s:0:"";s:26:"visibility_user_capability";s:0:"";s:9:"animation";s:0:"";s:15:"animation_delay";s:3:"0.0";s:2:"id";s:0:"";s:5:"class";s:0:"";s:4:"type";s:9:"rich-text";}}}

Our Why

There are so many reasons we think our mission is a critical one for the North American Church at this time.

We can no longer borrow the faith of our parents

Research from Pew Charitable Trusts` U.S. Religious Knowledge Survey illustrates that less than a 1/3 of American Christians can correctly answer 50% of questions about the core teachings, history, and leading figures of their faith traditions. 57% of American Christians believe other religions can lead to eternal life (Ponce Foundation). If we are ever to actively pursue putting Christ's teachings into daily practice, we must know what they are. If we are going to claim to be Orthodox Christians, we simply mush know what that means. What does it require we do, and alternatively, what does it require we don't do? Faithtree supports priests, people and parishes in answering these questions by creating engaging and interactive resources that teach the Faith, in the fullness of the Orthodox understanding and ethos, and taught by some of the Orthodox Church's most seasoned clergy, theologians and professionals. We envision a future where all of us seek to actively grow in our spiritual life, and not simply rely on the history of our forefathers.

Many of us don't read the salvific Gospel of Jesus Christ

According to the Barna Group and the American Bible Society, we Americans love our Bibles-we just don't want to read them. Less than 25% of Americans said they read their Bible on a regular basis (four or more times a week). A Gallup Poll reports that nearly 50% of Christians who attend church weekly do not believe that the Bible is the actual Word of God. This is no different for Orthodox Christians. A growing identification of the need to connect the timeless principles of Holy Scripture and the ever-present problems of day-to-day living is unmistakable. One of the things that makes the Faithtree team most excited is our passion about teaching in the language of our day. We don't use too many $10 words. While we understand we will never fully grasp all that the Orthodox Faith, or our Holy Tradition offers us, we are passionate about helping people engage from where they are. This is an intentional effort to help bridge the gap between the past and the present, the conceptual and the practical and to address the growing expressed concern that the Church is'too hard to understand'.

";s:10:"margin_top";s:0:"";s:17:"margin_top_medium";s:0:"";s:21:"margin_top_responsive";s:0:"";s:13:"margin_bottom";s:0:"";s:20:"margin_bottom_medium";s:0:"";s:24:"margin_bottom_responsive";s:0:"";s:11:"margin_left";s:0:"";s:18:"margin_left_medium";s:0:"";s:22:"margin_left_responsive";s:0:"";s:12:"margin_right";s:0:"";s:19:"margin_right_medium";s:0:"";s:23:"margin_right_responsive";s:0:"";s:18:"responsive_display";s:0:"";s:18:"visibility_display";s:0:"";s:26:"visibility_user_capability";s:0:"";s:9:"animation";s:0:"";s:15:"animation_delay";s:3:"0.0";s:2:"id";s:0:"";s:5:"class";s:0:"";s:4:"type";s:9:"rich-text";}}s:13:"5a01daa1e98af";O:8:"stdClass":5:{s:4:"node";s:13:"5a01daa1e98af";s:4:"type";s:6:"module";s:6:"parent";s:13:"5a01da4317b3d";s:8:"position";i:0;s:8:"settings";O:8:"stdClass":21:{s:4:"text";s:1346:"

Many of us have stopped going to church

Pew Research Center for Religion and Public Life reports that only 36% of adults in America attend religious services at least once a week. For Orthodox Christians, that percentage is even smaller (31%). We at Faithtree Resources understand the local parish to be the most important place for our people to engage. We don't believe we should 'do church' online, or that we can just "pray it out at home alone". At Faithtree Resources, we want to support relationships with spiritual mentors like the priest. We want our people to value and participate actively in the sacramental life of the Church. And we think it should all happen at the local parish.

 

We are called to share the fullness of the Truth of the Good New of Jesus Christ, which is most fully expressed in the One, Holy, Catholic and Apostolic Church.

Many folks today lack the deep understanding of how applying the teachings of the Church can directly impact their life for the Kingdom, and for the better. Application is putting into practice what we already know (see Mark 4:24 and Hebrews 5:14) and answers the question of "Why does it matter>" Faithtree believes that by doing that as Christ showed us0in community and together, that can happen most fully.

Our How

With a mission to aid our communities in helping Orthodox Christians to live like Christians, our team has begun to think of ourselves as:

;s:0:"";s:18:"visibility_display";s:0:"";s:26:"visibility_user_capability";s:0:"";s:2:"id";s:0:"";s:5:"class";s:0:"";}}s:13:"5a01db5e1be98";O:8:"stdClass":5:{s:4:"node";s:13:"5a01db5e1be98";s:4:"type";s:12:"column-group";s:6:"parent";s:13:"5a01db5e12eb6";s:8:"position";i:0;s:8:"settings";s:0:"";}s:13:"5a01db5e1c0ab";O:8:"stdClass":5:{s:4:"node";s:13:"5a01db5e1c0ab";s:4:"type";s:6:"column";s:6:"parent";s:13:"5a01db5e1be98";s:8:"position";i:0;s:8:"settings";O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:4:"size";i:50;}}s:13:"5a01db5e1c145";O:8:"stdClass":5:{s:4:"node";s:13:"5a01db5e1c145";s:4:"type";s:6:"column";s:6:"parent";s:13:"5a01db5e1be98";s:8:"position";i:1;s:8:"settings";O:8:"stdClass":1:{s:4:"size";i:50;}}s:13:"5a01db6a6f1c2";O:8:"stdClass":5:{s:4:"node";s:13:"5a01db6a6f1c2";s:4:"type";s:6:"module";s:6:"parent";s:13:"5a01db5e1c0ab";s:8:"position";i:0;s:8:"settings";O:8:"stdClass":21:{s:4:"text";s:1407:"Protectors. Not like Superman, or the Armed Forces, of course. But rather, our team thinks of ourselves as protectors of people, resources and Tradition. We take extraordinary efforts to ensure that we are protecting the people who work with us and for us. For the most part, we are volunteers, but we are committed to protecting our team and preserving a focus on the spiritual life, which means we pray together. A lot. We also are committed to protecting the Holy Tradition of the Ancient Christian Faith. This means we work with clergy and theologians to ensure that our teachings are theologically accurate. It means we work with doctors, teachers, youth workers, etc.,to make sure our resources are edifying and beneficial for our audience. And it means we stretch and steward every dollar we are entrusted with to its fullest capacity and to the best of our abilities. We take people's trust in us very seriously. Collaborators.Listen, it takes a village, that's for sure. To live out the Christian faith in this day and age, we need a tribe! And by working collaboratively with hierarchs, priests, theologians, therapist, doctors, educators, lay leaders and other seaoned thinkers from all over the Orthodox Church, we ensure our materialls are vetted through the eyes of many trusted leaders, many times. Side bonus is collaboration also makes the work super fun.";s:10:"margin_top";s:0:"";s:17:"margin_top_medium";s:0:"";s:21:"margin_top_responsive";s:0:"";s:13:"margin_bottom";s:0:"";s:20:"margin_bottom_medium";s:0:"";s:24:"margin_bottom_responsive";s:0:"";s:11:"margin_left";s:0:"";s:18:"margin_left_medium";s:0:"";s:22:"margin_left_responsive";s:0:"";s:12:"margin_right";s:0:"";s:19:"margin_right_medium";s:0:"";s:23:"margin_right_responsive";s:0:"";s:18:"responsive_display";s:0:"";s:18:"visibility_display";s:0:"";s:26:"visibility_user_capability";s:0:"";s:9:"animation";s:0:"";s:15:"animation_delay";s:3:"0.0";s:2:"id";s:0:"";s:5:"class";s:0:"";s:4:"type";s:9:"rich-text";}}s:13:"5a01db7d5fb53";O:8:"stdClass":5:{s:4:"node";s:13:"5a01db7d5fb53";s:4:"type";s:6:"module";s:6:"parent";s:13:"5a01db5e1c145";s:8:"position";i:0;s:8:"settings";O:8:"stdClass":21:{s:4:"text";s:981:"The Application Police. Perhaps the Faithtree team's biggest passion is focusing on application. This means a relentless pursuit of educating in simple, practical and immediately applicable ways. The Orthodox Christian Faith is so rich, so full of God's Truth in its fullness. But if we don't know how to actually apply it, what good does it do us? Translators. Okay, this word is tricky, because we're not Biblical Scholars (though we've worked with quite a few on our materials), and we aren't linguistics specialist, either (worked with a few of those, as well). So saying we are translators might seem a bit deceitful. However, we are committed to translating the teachings of the Faith into a language our people understand. That may look like digital media, it may look like great story-telling, but by speaking in the language of our day, we can share the Good News of Jesus Christ in a way our people can listen to, and God willing, hear.";s:10:"margin_top";s:0:"";s:17:"margin_top_medium";s:0:"";s:21:"margin_top_responsive";s:0:"";s:13:"margin_bottom";s:0:"";s:20:"margin_bottom_medium";s:0:"";s:24:"margin_bottom_responsive";s:0:"";s:11:"margin_left";s:0:"";s:18:"margin_left_medium";s:0:"";s:22:"margin_left_responsive";s:0:"";s:12:"margin_right";s:0:"";s:19:"margin_right_medium";s:0:"";s:23:"margin_right_responsive";s:0:"";s:18:"responsive_display";s:0:"";s:18:"visibility_display";s:0:"";s:26:"visibility_user_capability";s:0:"";s:9:"animation";s:0:"";s:15:"animation_delay";s:3:"0.0";s:2:"id";s:0:"";s:5:"class";s:0:"";s:4:"type";s:9:"rich-text";}}}

item.title: Removing Barriers
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
disability and the gospel > removing barriers

A Step by Step Guide to Making Your Parish
Disability-Friendly

Purchase Now

Did you know that over 54 million Americans--or one out of every five individuals--have a disability?

That means one out of five people in our churches! People with disabilities are considered one of the world's largest under-represented groups. The Church is largely unprepared for the burgeoning disabled population. What provisions or programs has your parish taken to insure the safety, inclusion and full participation in the life of the church for persons with disability?
Do the programs and physical facilities of your church invite persons with disability to participate in the life of the Church or do they exclude full participation by creating barriers?
Sadly today, too many families have felt unwelcome, or at the very least, unnoticed by the churches they attend.

Purchase Now

Try before you buy.

Download chapter one for free

[contact-form-7 id="345" title="Removing Barriers"]

Purchase Options

Removing Barriers

Guidebook

$30 - Add to Cart

Reviews

Best training ever!

We had no idea we needed this! Thank you, Faithtree for such an incredible book!

Ashley H. - Riverside Church.

Best training ever!

We had no idea we needed this! Thank you, Faithtree for such an incredible book!

Ashley H. - Riverside Church.

Did you know that over 54 million Americans--or one out of every five individuals--have a disability?

That means one out of five people in our churches! People with disabilities are considered one of the world's largest under-represented groups. The Church is largely unprepared for the burgeoning disabled population. What provisions or programs has your parish taken to insure the safety, inclusion and full participation in the life of the church for persons with disability? Do the programs and physical facilities of your church invite persons with disability to participate in the life of the Church or do they exclude full participation by creating barriers? Sadly today, too many families have felt unwelcome, or at the very least, unnoticed by the churches they attend.

Did you know that over 54 million Americans--or one out of every five individuals--have a disability?

That means one out of five people in our churches! People with disabilities are considered one of the world's largest under-represented groups. The Church is largely unprepared for the burgeoning disabled population. What provisions or programs has your parish taken to insure the safety, inclusion and full participation in the life of the church for persons with disability? Do the programs and physical facilities of your church invite persons with disability to participate in the life of the Church or do they exclude full participation by creating barriers? Sadly today, too many families have felt unwelcome, or at the very least, unnoticed by the churches they attend.

What is Lorem Ipsum?

Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry. Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book. It has survived not only five centuries, but also the leap into electronic typesetting, remaining essentially unchanged. It was popularised in the 1960s with the release of Letraset sheets containing Lorem Ipsum passages, and more recently with desktop publishing software like Aldus PageMaker including versions of Lorem Ipsum.

item.title: Removing Barriers
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
A Step by Step Guide to Making Your Parish Disability-Friendly

 

Did you know that over 54 million Americans—or one out of every five individuals—have a disability? That means one out of five people in our churches! People with disabilities are considered one of the world’s largest under-represented groups. The Church is largely unprepared for the burgeoning disabled population. What provisions or programs has your parish taken to insure the safety, inclusion and full participation in the life of the church for persons with disability?  Do the programs and physical facilities of your church invite persons with disability to participate in the life of the Church or do they exclude full participation by creating barriers?  Sadly today, too many families have felt unwelcome, or at the very least, unnoticed by the churches they attend.

We can help.
item.excerpt:encoded: A Step by Step Guide to Making Your Parish Disability-Friendly

item.title: Lionheart Sessions
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
ABOUT THE SESSIONS

WHAT IS INCLUDED

• 4 Sessions on 2 DVDs • Leader Guide • 10 Participant workbooks • Digital collateral to customize and print.
The Pursuit is a four week curriculum designed to engage the men in your parish into the life of the Church. Seasoned Orthodox clergy, theologians and professionals guide men through lessons on: men as servant-leaders, men in relationships, overcoming the obstacles that stand in the way of authentic manhood, and the pursuit of God in community. It is our prayer that these sessions will lead Orthodox Christian men to encountering the One True God Man, our Lord Jesus Christ.

item.title: The Relationship Project - Episode 1: Identity
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
INCLUDES EPISODE 1: IDENTITY, LESSON NOTES, AND ADDITIONAL FACILITATOR GUIDE!

WHAT IS THE RELATIONSHIP PROJECT?

Our young people today are facing difficult questions and situations in their lives, challenged by what society encourages as they face conflicting ideologies from peers, their schools, and the media. There is a disconnect between those con icting ideologies and what the Church teaches as truth. Faithtree believes that the questions our teens are asking cannot be addressed by a ten-minute sermon or by simple statements about what the Church does and does not support. They require deeper discussion, exploration, reflection, and explanation. And this process must take place in the context of deep and meaningful relationships between teens and their spiritual leaders and peers. At the end of the day, it is all about relationships. It is in and through relationships that we grow closer to our Lord and Creator. It is in and through relationships that we learn who we are and who we were created to be. And it is in and through relationships with teens that we can effectively teach them. Through this program, you can: • Connect the teens in your parish to rich theological content in a language they can understand and in a format they connect with • Offer your teens a space where they can feel comfortable to bring their questions and struggles • Facilitate the building of real community resulting in a support system of peers, mentors, and spiritual leaders As we have beta tested this material in many different youth ministry settings, we have been amazed to watch teenagers open up, ask profound questions, nd true peace in the truth, develop real relationships with peers and leaders, and grow deeply connected to the Church. It is amazing how when we simply open up a space to teenagers where they can come as they are and bring all of their questions and struggles, they are open to learning and want to keep coming back. Teens are yearning for truth and faith. When we embrace them, listen to them, love them, laugh with them, encourage them, and then teach them in this context, they feel a part of Christ’s Church and are open to receiving it. It is within this context that our teens will desire to learn about and grow close to Christ and His Church and will prepare to go out into the world grounded in truth and love. Above all, it is the aim of youth ministry to establish and strengthen the connection between our teens and Christ. We think we have found a pretty cool formula in which to do that.

WHO IS THE RELATIONSHIP PROJECT FOR?

You’re a clergyman, lay leader, youth worker or parent who is struggling to get the youth of the parish involved and engaged in the life of the Church. The product is presented in a fresh, culturally competent way. Beta-tests we’ve run throughout the country confirm what our team suspected: invite teens in the right way, and they’ll show up. Engage them in the right conversations and they’ll stay. Embrace them with love and create a space for them to wrestle with all things teen-related, and they’ll keep coming back. By the grace of God, somewhere in there, transformation happens. Relationships happen. You passionately want to provide the Church’s teachings, but truthfully, you don’t know how to begin the hard conversations and have the hard discussions about all that faces our kids these days. The Relationship Project is somewhat extraordinary because it tackles all the big topics facing our teens today. In the first two episodes released today, we cover issues of identity and intimacy setting the stage for the episodes to come on loneliness, physical desire and attraction, marriage, and in light of all that, dating. Our team has referred to it as the Masters Degree in Relationship for youth. And the cool part is, our team has done ALL the heavy lifting for you. Faithtree enlisted over 20 clergy, therapists, counselor, theologians, youth workers and parents to articulate the theology for you. Then we created a killer film series that is aesthetically beautiful and according to our teens, “not lame”. (Phew.)  All you have to do is press play and read the words written in your Facilitator Guide. We got the rest. You’re a parent, priest or parishioner who wants to engage the teens in your church but you have limited resources, support, and even, know-how. This part makes me super happy. As a former youth worker for over two decades, I know how isolated I felt sometimes in youth ministry. I know how hard limited funds, limited volunteers, and even, limited time when kids weren’t at soccer- made it feel to do the job in a way that glorified God. The Relationship Project helps to fix that. We have brought on a staff member to the Faithtree Team, to help solely with the needs of our churches that purchase this product. In doing this, we essentially give you a direct connection to a youth worker, with a degree in ministry and a Masters of Divinity, who will hold your hand through all of it. No more isolation.

WHAT ARE PEOPLE SAYING ABOUT THE RELATIONSHIP PROJECT?

This is a coordinated pan-Orthodox teaching. Essential Apologetics of our time. A positive message in support of living an Orthodox Christian life is found in Faithtree Resources.  - The Very Reverend Dr. Chad Hatfield, President, St. Vladimir’s Orthodox Seminary Faithtree Resources, looking to meet the needs of our faithful, has produced content that gives such insight. Relationships-with peers, family, church community and others—are the context for identity formation. Thank you Faithtree, for this valuable and high-quality program. - Carole Buleza, M.A., Director of the Antiochian Orthodox Department of Christian Education It is fantastic to see the Church take on the tough issues in our world today.  We know the answer is Christ, but this program gets through in a way that brings our kids closer to Christ and the Church and arms them with reasons they can understand. This series is a Don’t-Miss for both adults and their kids. As parents, we need the tools to help our kids forge through as strong Christians. This program not only gives both of us the tools, it does it in such an effective way that there is real buy in. - Cindy Karos Great content! I’m amazed it’s being given away for free. I would recommend it to anyone. - Liz Gray This video series has helped me enormously. Our youth ministry team is actively implementing your strategies and suggestions for engaging our teens. Thank you Faithtree Resources! - Robin El Habr
item.excerpt:encoded:
Through this program, you can:

• Connect the teens in your parish to rich theological content in a language they can understand and in a format they connect with • Offer your teens a space where they can feel comfortable to bring their questions and struggles • Facilitate the building of real community resulting in a support system of peers, mentors, and spiritual leaders

item.title: The Relationship Project - Episode 2: Intimacy

item.title: Intentional Parenting In A Reckless World
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
Intentional Parenting in a Reckless World is a 75-minute presentation by Faithtree Resources Founder and Executive Director, Michelle Moujaes, MSW.
In this talk, Michelle gives practical information and hands-on application for anyone who has kids, works with kids, or even just knows kids. Grandparents, godparents, teachers, clergy, neighbors, mentors and certainly moms and dads would benefit from this content.
With uncanny transparency, humor and wit, Michelle delivers a jam-packed presentation on God’s design for Christian parenting that you won’t want to miss.
item.excerpt:encoded:

item.title: test2
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
Where does it come from? Contrary to popular belief, Lorem Ipsum is not simply random text. It has roots in a piece of classical Latin literature from 45 BC, making it over 2000 years old. Richard McClintock, a Latin professor at Hampden-Sydney College in Virginia, looked up one of the more obscure Latin words, consectetur, from a Lorem Ipsum passage, and going through the cites of the word in classical literature, discovered the undoubtable source. Lorem Ipsum comes from sections 1.10.32 and 1.10.33 of "de Finibus Bonorum et Malorum" (The Extremes of Good and Evil) by Cicero, written in 45 BC. This book is a treatise on the theory of ethics, very popular during the Renaissance. The first line of Lorem Ipsum, "Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet..", comes from a line in section 1.10.32.
The standard chunk of Lorem Ipsum used since the 1500s is reproduced below for those interested. Sections 1.10.32 and 1.10.33 from "de Finibus Bonorum et Malorum" by Cicero are also reproduced in their exact original form, accompanied by English versions from the 1914 translation by H. Rackham.

item.title: test3
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
What is Lorem Ipsum?

Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry. Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book. It has survived not only five centuries, but also the leap into electronic typesetting, remaining essentially unchanged. It was popularised in the 1960s with the release of Letraset sheets containing Lorem Ipsum passages, and more recently with desktop publishing software like Aldus PageMaker including versions of Lorem Ipsum.  

What is Lorem Ipsum?

Lorem Ipsum is simply dummy text of the printing and typesetting industry. Lorem Ipsum has been the industry's standard dummy text ever since the 1500s, when an unknown printer took a galley of type and scrambled it to make a type specimen book. It has survived not only five centuries, but also the leap into electronic typesetting, remaining essentially unchanged. It was popularised in the 1960s with the release of Letraset sheets containing Lorem Ipsum passages, and more recently with desktop publishing software like Aldus PageMaker including versions of Lorem Ipsum.

item.title: Lionheart Sessions Starter Kit
item.dc:creator: developer
item.content:encoded:
ABOUT THE SESSIONS

WHAT IS INCLUDED

• 4 Sessions on 2 DVDs • Leader Guide • 10 Participant workbooks • Digital collateral to customize and print.
The Pursuit is a four week curriculum designed to engage the men in your parish into the life of the Church. Seasoned Orthodox clergy, theologians and professionals guide men through lessons on: men as servant-leaders, men in relationships, overcoming the obstacles that stand in the way of authentic manhood, and the pursuit of God in community. It is our prayer that these sessions will lead Orthodox Christian men to encountering the One True God Man, our Lord Jesus Christ.
